newsitem.title: UK: S&P raises Guardian Re claims paying to A minus.
newsitem.headline: S&P raises Guardian Re claims paying to A minus.

text.p: Standard & Poor's said on Monday it had raised its claims-paying ability rating of Guardian Reinsurance Company (Guardian Re) to A minus from BB plus.
S&P also said it had removed Guardian Re's claims-paying ability rating from Creditwatch, where it was placed with positive implications on August 16, 1996.
"The rating reflects Guardian Re's strategic importance to its new parent, Transatlantic Reinsurance Company (Transatlantic Re), of the U.S. (rated AA)," S&P said in a statement.
"On a stand alone basis, Guardian Re shows selective underwriting strategy, good operating performance and satisfactory capitalisation," S&P said.

"Partially offsetting these strengths, S&P believes that the company has a somewhat modest business position given its size, "follower' status and dependence upon traditional proportional relationships. The new ownership is expected to lead to an improvement in business position going forward," it said.

"Guardian Re's operating performance is expected to remain satisfactory in 1996 despite softening rates. In particular, S&P believes that published results will only slowly deteriorate due to the use of contingency reserves," the agency said.

Longer term, S&P said it believed Guardian Re would be able to strengthen it s business position, aided by its new parent, Transatlantic Re, by offering greater capacity and more complex non-proportional products.
